text: And Abraham took Ishmael his son, and all that were born in his house, and all that were bought with his money, every male among the men of Abraham's house; and circumcised the flesh of their foreskin in the selfsame day, as God had said unto him.
text_kjv: And Abraham took Ishmael his son, and all that were born in his house, and all that were bought with his money, every male among the men of Abraham's house; and circumcised the flesh of their foreskin in the selfsame day, as God had said unto him.
text_niv: On that very day Abraham took his son Ishmael and all those born in his household or bought with his money, every male in his household, and circumcised them, as God told him.
text_esv: Then Abraham took Ishmael his son and all those born in his house or bought with his money, every male among the men of Abraham's house, and he circumcised the flesh of their foreskins that very day, as God had said to him.
text_nlt: On that very day Abraham took his son, Ishmael, and every male in his household, including those born there and those he had bought. Then he circumcised them, cutting off their foreskins, just as God had told him.
text_msg: Then Abraham took his son Ishmael and all his servants, whether houseborn or purchased—every male in his household—and circumcised them, cutting off their foreskins that very day, just as God had told him.
text_nasb: Then Abraham took Ishmael his son, and all [the servants] who were born in his house and all who were bought with his money, every male among the men of Abraham's household, and circumcised the flesh of their foreskin in the very same day, as God had said to him.
context: Genesis 17:23 describes Abraham's immediate obedience to God's command to circumcise all the males in his household. Understanding the historical and cultural context provides deeper insight. Circumcision was not a common practice among the people surrounding Abraham. While some ancient cultures practiced ritualistic cutting of the foreskin for hygiene or as a rite of passage, God's specific command to Abraham established it as a sign of the covenant between Him and Abraham and his descendants. This covenant was distinct from other religious practices of the time, setting Abraham's lineage apart. The 'house' of Abraham wasn't simply his immediate family. It encompassed a large household, including servants, slaves (both born in his house and purchased), and their families. Wealth and status in that era were often measured by the size of one's household and possessions, including people. Abraham's wealth allowed him to purchase individuals, making them part of his extended family and subject to his authority. This verse highlights the encompassing nature of the covenant; it wasn't limited to blood relatives but extended to all under Abraham's care and protection. The speed of Abraham's obedience – 'in the selfsame day' – is also notable, reflecting his deep faith and commitment to God's word. This prompt obedience contrasts with later instances of doubt and wavering that Abraham experiences, showing the progression of his faith journey. The meticulous detail in listing the different groups circumcised emphasizes the comprehensive inclusion in the covenant.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 17:23 carries profound significance as it reveals the nature of God's covenant and the requirements for participating in it. Circumcision, in this context, is not merely a physical act; it is a symbolic representation of dedication and obedience to God. It signifies a separation from the ungodly practices of the surrounding cultures and a commitment to following God's commands. The inclusion of all males in Abraham's household, regardless of their origin or social status, highlights the universality of God's offer. The covenant was open to all who came under Abraham's authority and chose to align themselves with his faith. This foreshadows the later inclusion of Gentiles into God's family through faith in Christ. The 'selfsame day' obedience underlines the importance of immediate and unwavering faith. Abraham did not delay or question God's command but acted upon it immediately, demonstrating his trust in God's wisdom and sovereignty. This immediate action contrasts sharply with the delayed obedience seen elsewhere in Scripture and emphasizes the blessings that come from responding promptly to God's will. Circumcision was a visible, outward sign of an inward commitment, a physical reminder of their relationship with God. It was a symbol of cleansing and purification, representing a cutting away of the 'flesh' – the sinful nature – and a dedication to living a life pleasing to God. In the New Testament, circumcision gives way to baptism, a new symbol of entering into covenant with God through Christ.
application: The immediate application of Genesis 17:23 for modern Christians lies in understanding the importance of obedience and commitment to God's commands. While we are not called to physically circumcise, we are called to undergo a 'circumcision of the heart' (Romans 2:29), which involves turning away from selfish desires and embracing a life dedicated to serving God. This means promptly responding to God's call in our lives, whether it's through acts of service, acts of kindness, or simply living a life of integrity. Just as Abraham circumcised all in his household, we are called to influence those around us towards faith and righteousness. This doesn't mean forcing our beliefs on others, but rather, living a life that reflects God's love and truth, and creating environments where others can encounter Christ. This can involve creating a welcoming atmosphere in our homes, workplaces, and communities, where people feel safe to explore their faith and ask questions. The act of circumcision for Abraham was costly. It was risky and involved many people. Likewise, following Christ often involves sacrifice and discomfort. It may mean making difficult choices, giving up personal desires, or facing opposition from others. However, as Abraham demonstrated, the blessings of obedience far outweigh the costs. We can learn to practice instant obedience by asking God to reveal areas of our lives where we are resistant to his will. We can then pray for the strength and courage to surrender those areas to him. Remembering that God's commands are not meant to restrict us but to lead us into a life of freedom and fulfillment can motivate us to obey promptly. Consider how you can act immediately in obedience in one area of your life today. How can you include those around you into experiencing the grace of God and understanding His commands?
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the example of Abraham's obedience. Forgive me for the times I have delayed or resisted your call in my life. Help me to have a heart that is quick to hear your voice and quick to obey. Grant me the strength and courage to make the sacrifices necessary to follow you wholeheartedly. Lord, show me the areas of my life where I am holding back from you. Reveal to me any hidden idols or selfish desires that are hindering my obedience. Fill me with your Holy Spirit, that I may live a life pleasing to you in every way. Help me to influence others towards faith and righteousness, creating an environment where they can encounter your love and truth. I pray that my life may be a testament to your goodness and faithfulness. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: While not explicitly stated, circumcision likely symbolized purity, fertility, and dedication. It marked a physical separation from the world and a commitment to God's covenant, affecting future generations through the lineage of Abraham's descendants. It served as a constant reminder of the agreement with God.
faqs.question: Why was circumcision chosen as the sign of the covenant?

faqs.answer: Yes, it would have been a significant undertaking. It involved a considerable amount of time, resources, and likely some resistance from those being circumcised, particularly the adult males who may not have understood or agreed with the practice initially. Physical pain would also be a factor.
faqs.question: Was it difficult for Abraham to circumcise so many people at once?

faqs.answer: In the New Testament, circumcision is replaced by baptism as the sign of the covenant. Baptism symbolizes a spiritual cleansing and a new life in Christ. It reflects the inward change of heart, rather than an outward mark, as emphasized in the Old Covenant.
faqs.question: How does this event relate to the New Testament?

faqs.answer: No, it reflects the historical reality of the time. The Bible does not necessarily endorse every practice it describes. While slavery existed, the scriptures also contain principles of justice, compassion, and freedom that ultimately challenge the institution of slavery. Christians recognize slavery as morally wrong.
faqs.question: Does this verse imply that slavery is morally acceptable?

faqs.answer: A 'circumcised heart,' as mentioned in Romans 2:29, refers to an inward transformation where one's affections and desires are centered on God, rather than selfish pursuits. It's a spiritual separation from sin and a dedication to living according to God's will, guided by the Holy Spirit.
